newsitem.title: FRANCE: Lyonnaise boss Monod quits Havas board.
newsitem.headline: Lyonnaise boss Monod quits Havas board.

text.p: Jerome Monod, chairman of French utilities firm Lyonnaise des Eaux, has resigned from the board of Havas, spokeswomen at the two companies said on Thursday.
They were commenting on reports in daily papers Les Echos and Le Figaro which said Monod was critical of some aspects of a recent accord between Havas and Compagnie Generale des Eaux (CGE).
The Lyonnaise spokeswoman declined to give a reason for Monod's move. The company currently owns "less than one percent" of Havas's capital, she said.
Earlier this month CGE became the biggest shareholder in Havas under an accord which also involved Havas becoming the largest shareholder in pay TV company Canal Plus.
Les Echos said Monod questioned the valuation of Generale des Images, a subsidiary of CGE, and of the 19.3 percent of Canal Plus in the deal.
He sought an independent valuation of Canal Plus, including its merger with the European interests of South Africa's Nethold, but was turned down, the paper said.
Le Figaro said Lyonnaise des Eaux only learnt about the accord with CGE from press reports.
The Havas and Lyonnaise spokeswomen declined to comment.
Havas is to hold a shareholders' meeting on March 28 to approve the accord with CGE, the capital increase reserved for CGE and the appointment of new board members from CGE.

Five seats on the board will be held by CGE. These will be Guy Dejouany, CGE's honorary chairman who already had a seat, CGE chairman Jean-Marie Messier and three of his advisers, Guillaume Hannezo, Eric Licoys and Jean-Pascal Tranie, the Havas spokeswoman said.
The Havas-CGE-Canal Plus accord has shaken up some of Havas's established alliances, because it has linked up with competitors of its existing partners, notably in television and telecommunications.

Among the television interests of Lyonnaise des Eaux are Lyonnaise Cable, a cable TV network which cables 2.2 million homes, 34 percent of M6, which is now France's second largest privately-owned terrestrial TV channel, and thematic channel Paris Premiere.
It also has a 10 percent direct holding in TPS (Television par satellite, one of two French digital satellite TV offerings).

In telecommunications, Lyonnaise has said it is interested in competing in operating local loop connections using its cable networks once European telecoms markets open to competition from next January.
CGE is active in the mobile telephony market and has said it aims to become the main competitor of France Telecom after telecommunications liberalisation.
Michel Bon, chairman of France Telecom, still has a seat on the Havas board. France Telecom has declined to comment on whether he will stay.
